awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Efficient Learning of Process-Structure-Property Models in Value-Driven Materials Design
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports research that will contribute knowledge towards the efficient discovery of new material systems.  New materials are expected to have a significant impact in a broad range of application domains, ranging from biomedical systems to infrastructure and energy systems, improving the efficiencies of these systems and creating new capabilities that have so far been technologically out of reach.  In current practice, however, the development of new materials is very costly and time-consuming because it relies mostly on physical testing and experimentation. Rather than focusing on the development of a specific new material, this award aims to develop modeling approaches and learning algorithms that allow for more efficient and effective exploration and discovery of new materials in general. The results of the investigation will help material scientists and engineers understand when to rely on mathematical analysis models or when to use physical experiments so that new information about so far unexplored materials can be gathered efficiently, and so that the materials design effort can be efficiently guided towards materials with desired and valuable properties. The research is expected to lead to a dramatic acceleration of the materials design process with significant competitive advantages to US industry. Through a university-industry consortium these innovations will be transferred into industrial practice.  All new models and algorithms will be shared open-source, and the research findings, methods and tools will be incorporated in on-campus and on-line courses, with the potential to reach a large number of students, researchers and practitioners.  

The main research objective of this project is to critically evaluate the relative merits of different modeling formalisms and approaches for capturing and utilizing materials domain knowledge in a way that is most valuable to the designer. In the design process, multiple information sources will be combined, including bulk material tests, low-cost experimental assays, and physics-based multiscale Process-Structure-Property models.  The hypothesis is that combining information from a portfolio of information sources with synergistic cost-accuracy trade-offs leads to a more efficient and effective design process. A second focus is on combining the information from these sources into integrative reduced-order Process-Structure-Property linkages.  These linkages support learning through Bayesian updating as new information is acquired, and they are computationally inexpensive and therefore well-suited for searching the design space.  The overall design framework will be applied and validated in the context of dual phase steels.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The research objective of this proposal was to critically evaluate the relative merits of different modeling formalisms and approaches for capturing and utilizing materials domain knowledge in a way that is most valuable for materials design. When searching for new materials with desired engineering properties, researchers rely mostly on experiments because of the limited availability and accuracy of physics-based models for predicting bulk properties.  However, since experiments are expensive and time-consuming, a materials design process that relies on a large number of such experiments is itself very costly and slow, hampering the opportunity for innovation in materials design.

The project team investigated systematically how to take full advantage of the information collected from experiments so that new materials with desired properties can be identified with as few experiments as possible. This is particularly challenging because of the inherent variability in the experiments, meaning that, when producing multiple samples of the same material, the corresponding property measurements will vary slightly from one sample to the next.  Building on probability and decision theory, the research team developed an algorithm that considers all the previously obtained experimental data in order to determine which set of additional experiments should be performed.  The algorithm searches for the set of experiments that maximize the expected value of information. 

As a representative design problem, in this project we focused on mechanical properties of materials fabricated using advanced processing techniques. As illustrated in Figure 1, an initial set of experiments acts as a starting point to the sequential optimization of the material value as a function of the mechanical properties. The experiments are then used to fit Gaussian process regression models and learn from them to propose a new set of experiments that maximize the value of information and provides the largest expected improvement in the material value. By focusing on the maximization of the value of information, the proposed framework automatically balances the tradeoff between exploration and exploitation. The approach results in exploration-driven samples in areas where the uncertainty due to variability is large so that there is still a possibility that more valuable materials may be found in these so-far-underexplored areas.  It also results in exploitation-driven samples in areas near the best-so-far solution, aiming to find even better materials or aiming to improve the value estimation of the best-so-far.

As illustrated in Figure 2, the research team characterized the performance of the algorithm by performing a very large number of simulations employing synthetic (but representative) materials models. Figure 2(a-e) show a typical progression of the optimization with the green marker representing the predicted optimum at a given iteration and the yellow star representing the ground truth optimum. Figure 2(f) is the ground truth material value in the considered processing space calculated from the synthetic mechanical properties. The progression shows how the algorithm first selectively explores the space of alternatives and then focuses on the best-so-far neighborhood performing more experiments there as represented by the size of the markers signifying the sample size at each set of processing parameters. Figure 2(e, f) also show that the regions of low material value (in blue) are not tested nearly as much. In those areas, the algorithm can conclude based on relatively few material tests that the properties will not lead to a valuable result.

The research team illustrated the use of this algorithm for designing materials for metal additive manufacturing, specifically, Laser-Powder Bed Fusion (L-PBF). The material properties obtained through L-BPF do not only depend on the material composition of the metal powder, but also on process parameters such as laser power and scan speed.  By applying the new value-of-information maximization approach, the team showed that process parameters resulting in desired engineering properties could be identified with significantly fewer experiments than through traditional randomized exploration approaches.

The impact of this work extends beyond the materials design context.  There are many engineering problems in which design space exploration is limited by the cost of experimentation.  The ability to arrive at valuable engineering solutions more quickly with fewer experiments has broad applicability and the potential for significant improvements in innovation and competitiveness.  For instance, the approach developed in this project is currently being used to explore new materials for batteries that are lighter, cheaper and more stable with less environmental impact.  Any improvement in battery performance will have a significant societal impact as we move towards an increasingly electrified infrastructure network.


Last Modified: 09/28/2023
Modified by: Christiaan J Paredis
